Sentencas: Two Cu-based anode cermets suitable for direct hydrocarbon oxidation in Solid Oxide Fuel Cells (SOFC) based on yttria stabilized zirconia (YSZ) electrolyte were tested in the temperature range (500-800A degrees C).
Titulo: Preparation and characterization of copper based cermet anodes for use in solid oxide fuel cells at intermediate temperatures

Sentencas: The ceramic components were CeO2 and the perovskite La0.75Sr0.25Cr0.5Mn0.5O3-d (LSCM).
Titulo: Preparation and characterization of copper based cermet anodes for use in solid oxide fuel cells at intermediate temperatures

Sentencas: The cermets were made in both the form of pellets and films applied onto the YSZ electrolytes.
Titulo: Preparation and characterization of copper based cermet anodes for use in solid oxide fuel cells at intermediate temperatures

Sentencas: Pellets exhibited good mechanical strength and resistance to fracture in both oxidized and reduced state.
Titulo: Preparation and characterization of copper based cermet anodes for use in solid oxide fuel cells at intermediate temperatures

Sentencas: Cu-LSCM cermets exhibited good redox cycling behavior between 700-800A degrees C. Reduction temperature plays a significant role on final morphology with Cu segregation occurring at 800A degrees C. Cu-LSCM films were found to exhibit lower polarization resistances than Cu-CeO2 under 5% H-2.
Titulo: Preparation and characterization of copper based cermet anodes for use in solid oxide fuel cells at intermediate temperatures

Sentencas: Examination of the data revealed a poorer contact of the Cu-CeO2 electrode with the YSZ surface than the Cu-LSCM electrode.
Titulo: Preparation and characterization of copper based cermet anodes for use in solid oxide fuel cells at intermediate temperatures

Sentencas: Reduction temperature should be less than 750A degrees C to ensure suitable microstructure and adhesion of both film electrodes with the electrolyte.
Titulo: Preparation and characterization of copper based cermet anodes for use in solid oxide fuel cells at intermediate temperatures
